text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

text: 1    OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: GUIDANCE NOTE SERIES
label: HH1

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH1

text: HUMANITARIAN DATA ETHICS
label: HH1

text: KEY TAKEAWAYS:
label: HH1

text: •	 Ethics is the study of what is morally right and wrong, or a set of beliefs about what is morally
label: BODY

text: right and wrong. Ethics helps provide the foundation for norms, can be used to interpret
label: BODY

text: established norms and can be applied directly as guidance in situations for which norms, laws
label: BODY

text: and regulations do not provide direction.
label: BODY

text: •	 Humanitarian ethics has developed as a principle-based ethics, grounded in the principles of
label: BODY

text: humanity, impartiality, neutrality and independence that guide the provision of humanitarian
label: BODY

text: assistance and protection. Existing frameworks for humanitarian ethics must be expanded to
label: BODY

text: enable staff and organizations to navigate the challenges and opportunities of the digital age.
label: BODY

text: •	 Data ethics is the branch of ethics that studies and evaluates moral problems and offers
label: BODY

text: normative guidance related to data, algorithms, and corresponding practices. Common ethical
label: BODY

text: issues in data management include issues of fairness, validity, bias, ossification, transparency
label: BODY

text: and explainability, anonymity, privacy, and ownership of data and insights.
label: BODY

text: •	 In addition, a range of other ethical issues may arise in data-related projects in the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: sector, including: potential harmfulness of humanitarian action, difficulties in association,
label: BODY

text: complicity and moral entrapment, duties of care towards humanitarian staff and the 'cost-
label: BODY

text: effectiveness conundrum’.
label: BODY

text: •	 Humanitarian organizations can improve ethical deliberation and decision-making in data-
label: BODY

text: management by: (i) establishing clear codes of conduct for ethical data management; (ii)
label: BODY

text: supporting staff to identify, understand and debate ethical issues using common tools; and (iii)
label: BODY

text: introducing ‘ethical audits’ as part of standard practice.
label: BODY

text: INTRODUCTION
label: HH1

text: Data responsibility is the safe, ethical and effective management of data.1 This note focuses on the ethical
label: BODY

text: aspects of humanitarian data management, ranging from standard exercises such as field-level data
label: BODY

text: collection and processing to more advanced applications of data science, such as predictive analytics.
label: BODY

text: This note aims to support humanitarian practitioners in identifying, assessing and addressing ethical
label: BODY

text: concerns that arise in data-related projects. It begins with an overview of humanitarian ethics and data
label: BODY

text: ethics, with a focus on the values that drive ethical decision-making in the two fields. It then introduces
label: BODY

text: some of the common ethical concerns and challenges that humanitarians may face in data management.
label: BODY

text: Finally, it provides recommendations for humanitarian organizations seeking to improve ethical
label: BODY

text: deliberation regarding the use and impact of data in their operations.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

text: Ethics is defined as the study of what is morally right and wrong, or a set of beliefs about what is morally
label: BODY

text: right and wrong.2 The role of ethics in guiding practice is essential in the context of a profession such as
label: BODY

text: humanitarian action, where individuals from a diverse range of backgrounds and value systems come
label: BODY

text: together in pursuit of a common goal: helping and protecting people affected by war and disasters.
label: BODY

text: Common ethical concerns in data management5
label: BODY

text: •	 Validity: is the data and/or model representative of what you want to measure?
label: BODY

text: •	 Bias and Fairness: is there a systematic skewing of the data collected and/or is there any prejudice
label: BODY

text: or favoritism in the data or model? (e.g. has there been an over- or underestimation of what is
label: BODY

text: being measured or are some members of the population more or less represented than others?)
label: BODY

text: •	 Ossification: is the model (or underlying data) codifying the current state of the world and thereby
label: BODY

text: making it harder to change? (e.g. are we building models that perpetuate or encore past mistakes)
label: BODY

text: •	 Transparency and Explainability: is there clear documentation of the data management process
label: BODY

text: and visibility on how the model or algorithm(s) function? (e.g. can someone not directly involved
label: BODY

text: in the process explain what is happening?)
label: BODY

text: •	 Privacy and Anonymity: is the data or its use revealing the identity of an individual or group of
label: BODY

text: people?
label: BODY

text: •	 Ownership of Data and Insights: are the rights to the data and related insights clearly defined?
label: BODY

text: (e.g. is it clear how decisions are made regarding how and by whom the data can be used, how
label: BODY

text: problems in or related to the data are rectified and other related issues?)
label: BODY

text: 2   Cambridge Dictionary, available here: https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/ethics.
label: BODY

text: 3    Hugo Slim, 2015. Humanitarian Ethics: A Guide to the Morality of Aid in War and Disaster, 118-119.
label: BODY

text: 4  Luciano Floridi, 2018. Soft Ethics and the Governance of the Digital, Philos. Technol. 31: 1.
label: BODY

text: 5   Luciano Floridi and Mariarosaria Taddeo, 2016. What is data Ethics?, Phil. Trans. R. Soc. A 374: 20160360.
label: BODY

text: “Ethics is not just being rational and affective. Our choices must also seek to
label: BODY

text: be effective... Acts are, therefore, the ultimate outcome of ethics. The practical
label: BODY

text: field of humanitarian ethics is deliberately known as humanitarian action
label: BODY

text: because of this basic moral insight that ethics without action is nonsensical.”3
label: BODY

text: - Hugo Slim, Humanitarian Ethics: A Guide to the Morality of Aid in War and Disaster
label: BODY

text: Ethics has a particularly important role to play in the domain of data management, as the technical tools
label: BODY

text: for managing data have evolved faster than the instruments that govern their use. As philosopher Luciano
label: BODY

text: Floridi argues, “ethics in general and digital ethics in particular cannot be a mere add-on (…) once digital
label: BODY

text: innovation has taken place, and possibly bad solutions have been implemented, less good alternatives
label: BODY

text: have been chosen, or mistakes have been made.”4 In a given sector, professionals must identify, assess and
label: BODY

text: develop strategies to mitigate the common ethical concerns that may arise in data management. As these
label: BODY

text: issues become clear, what is ‘good’ or ‘right’ from an ethical perspective should then inform emerging
label: BODY

text: policy and legal instruments that ultimately govern data management in the sector.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

text: HUMANITARIAN ETHICS
label: HH1

text: As Hugo Slim explains in Humanitarian Ethics: A Guide to the Morality of Aid in War and Disasters,
label: BODY

text: “Humanitarian ethics has developed as a principle-based ethics … grounded in the principles of humanity,
label: BODY

text: impartiality, neutrality and independence that have been developed to guide the provision of humanitarian
label: BODY

text: assistance and protection.”6 In Slim’s framing, principles specifically serve three main purposes in applied
label: BODY

text: ethics: to affirm moral norms, to act as constant operational guides to ethical decision-making and to
label: BODY

text: generate specific rules.7
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Principles
label: HH1

text: Source: OCHA on Message: Humanitarian Principles.8
label: BODY

text: These principles and related rules are enshrined in various codes of conduct now widely recognized as the
label: BODY

text: basis for ethical humanitarian practice, such as the Humanitarian Charter and Minimum Standards in
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Response, including the Sphere Core Standards and the Protection Principles9, the Core
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Standard10 and the Red Cross/NGO Code of Conduct.11 Though these frameworks serve as
label: BODY

text: useful guides to ethical decision making, they cannot simply be applied in practice across the complex
label: BODY

text: range of settings where humanitarians deliver assistance. Rather, as Slim notes, “they are typically
label: BODY

text: interpreted from within a situation. Humanitarian ethics is, therefore, about struggling to interpret ethical
label: BODY

text: limits and balancing various principles.”12
label: BODY

text: The interpretation of these principles becomes both more complex and more essential in areas of
label: BODY

text: humanitarian action where clear standards and sector-wide guidance are lacking. Humanitarian data
label: BODY

text: management is one such domain.
label: BODY

text: 6   Hugo Slim, 2015. Humanitarian Ethics: A Guide to the Morality of Aid in War and Disaster, 40.
label: BODY

text: 7    Ibid.
label: BODY

text: 8   OCHA on Message: Humanitarian Principles.
label: BODY

text: 9   Sphere Association, 2018. The Sphere Handbook: Humanitarian Charter and Minimum Standards in Humanitarian Response, fourth edition.
label: BODY

text: 10 CHS Alliance, Groupe URD, and The Sphere Project, 2014. Core Humanitarian Standard: Core Humanitarian Standard on Quality and Accountability.
label: BODY

text: 11  International Committee of the Red Cross and International Federation of the Red Cross, 1994. “Code of Conduct for the International Red Cross and
label: BODY

text: Red Crescent Movement and Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) in Disaster Relief”.
label: BODY

text: 12 Hugo Slim, 2015. Humanitarian Ethics: A Guide to the Morality of Aid in War and Disaster, 117.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

text: DATA ETHICS
label: HH1

text: Data ethics has emerged in recent years as a distinct area of ethical enquiry and research. In a 2017
label: BODY

text: whitepaper, the Open Data Institute (ODI) points to the growing importance of data ethics in public
label: BODY

text: discourse. “Increasingly,” ODI observes, “those collecting, sharing and working with data are exploring
label: BODY

text: the ethics of their practices and, in some cases, being forced to confront those ethics in the face of public
label: BODY

text: criticism.”13
label: BODY

text: According to Luciano Floridi and Mariarosario Taddeo, “[d]ata ethics can be defined as a branch of ethics
label: BODY

text: that studies and evaluates moral problems related to data (including generation, recording, curation,
label: BODY

text: processing, dissemination, sharing and use), algorithms (including artificial intelligence, artificial
label: BODY

text: agents, machine learning and robots) and corresponding practices (including responsible innovation,
label: BODY

text: programming, hacking and professional codes).”14 In practice, public sector institutions typically approach
label: BODY

text: data ethics as “a branch of ethics that evaluates data practices with the potential to adversely impact on
label: BODY

text: people and society — in data collection, sharing and use.”15
label: BODY

text: As data has become increasingly central to how public and private institutions operate, questions of data
label: BODY

text: ethics have grown more common in debates about the impact of data and technology on society. This
label: BODY

text: is seen most prominently in the global discourse around ethical Artificial Intelligence (AI). A landscape
label: BODY

text: analysis of global AI ethics frameworks published in September 2019 identifies a “convergence emerging
label: BODY

text: around five ethical principles (transparency, justice and fairness, non-maleficence, responsibility and
label: BODY

text: privacy), with substantive divergence in relation to how these principles are interpreted, why they are
label: BODY

text: deemed important, what issue, domain or actors they pertain to and how they should be implemented.”16
label: BODY

text: The presence of high-level principles alone, however, does not guarantee effective ethical deliberation and
label: BODY

text: decision-making.17
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian ethics forms a stronger foundation for debating issues around the ethical management of
label: BODY

text: data for humanitarian purposes than the various stand-alone frameworks for different areas of applied data
label: BODY

text: ethics. Existing frameworks for humanitarian ethics must be expanded to enable humanitarian staff and
label: BODY

text: organizations to navigate the new complexities that data management presents.
label: BODY

text: 13  Open Data Institute, 2017. Helping organizations navigate ethical concerns in their data practices.
label: BODY

text: 14  Luciano Floridi and Mariarosario Taddeo, 2016. What is data Ethics? Phil. Trans. R. Soc. A 374: 20160360.
label: BODY

text: 15  Open Data Institute, 2017. Helping organizations navigate ethical concerns in their data practices.
label: BODY

text: 16  Anna Jobin, Marcello Ienca and Effy Vayena, 2019. The global landscape of AI ethics guidelines. Nat Mach Intell 1, 389–399.
label: BODY

text: 17  Brent Mittelstadt, 2019. Principles alone cannot guarantee ethical AI. Nat Mach Intell 1, 501–507 (2019).
label: BODY

text: ETHICAL CONSIDERATIONS FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA MANAGEMENT
label: HH1

text: Humanitarians face difficult choices in delivering assistance and providing protection to populations
label: BODY

text: in crisis. While these different types of dilemmas pertain to humanitarian action as a whole, many of
label: BODY

text: them are particularly prominent or exacerbated in data-related projects. The table below presents some
label: BODY

text: common types of ethical dilemmas and offers examples of how they might manifest in humanitarian
label: BODY

text: data management. When assessing the ethical dimensions of a data-related project, humanitarians
label: BODY

text: must consider the dilemmas outlined below as well as the common concerns in data ethics (described
label: BODY

text: in more detail in the call-out box above), including: fairness, validity, bias, ossification, transparency and
label: BODY

text: explainability, anonymity, privacy, and ownership of data and insights.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

text: 18 These examples draw on the work of Hugo Slim and Jennifer Rubenstein, viz Hugo Slim, 2015. Humanitarian Ethics: A Guide to the Morality of Aid in
label: BODY

text: War and Disaster, 117 and Jennifer Rubenstein, 2015. Between Samaritans and States, 10-15.
label: BODY

text: Common ethical dilemmas
label: BODY

text: in humanitarian action18
label: BODY

text: Difficulties in association
label: HH1

text: Past work with partner
label: BODY

text: organizations from various
label: BODY

text: political, religious and other
label: BODY

text: backgrounds can create
label: BODY

text: tensions with new partners.
label: BODY

text: Potential harmfulness or
label: BODY

text: maleficence of humanitarian
label: BODY

text: action
label: BODY

text: Direct or indirect harm caused
label: BODY

text: by humanitarian response
label: BODY

text: activities.
label: BODY

text: A needs assessment is required to inform response activities. While the
label: BODY

text: data collected during the assessment enables humanitarian organizations
label: BODY

text: to more effectively target assistance based on need, it also reveals the
label: BODY

text: communities in which households have expressed unfavorable views about
label: BODY

text: local authorities. Local authorities obtain this data and systematically
label: BODY

text: exclude those households from future rounds of assistance, causing direct
label: BODY

text: harm. This compromises the protection of life and health of certain members
label: BODY

text: of the population and undermines the independence of the response as a
label: BODY

text: whole. Although aid organizations are not directly involved in this exclusion,
label: BODY

text: the use of data collected by humanitarians for maleficent purposes may
label: BODY

text: compromise their neutrality.
label: BODY

text: Scenarios in humanitarian data management
label: BODY

text: A humanitarian organization publicly announces a partnership with a
label: BODY

text: private sector technology firm that has also provided technology services
label: BODY

text: to intelligence agencies. Local political groups opposing the presence of the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian organization use the association with the firm to accuse the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian organization of spying. Engaging in this political controversy
label: BODY

text: endangers the humanitarian organization’s neutrality.
label: BODY

text: Complicity and moral
label: HH1

text: entrapment
label: BODY

text: Organizations actually cooperate
label: BODY

text: in serious wrongdoing,
label: BODY

text: intentionally or unintentionally,
label: BODY

text: or find themselves ‘trapped’ in
label: BODY

text: circumstances where they must
label: BODY

text: balance between continued
label: BODY

text: wrongdoing and ‘the greater
label: BODY

text: good’.
label: BODY

text: As a requirement for letting humanitarians into the country, local authorities
label: BODY

text: demand that a ‘scientific approach’ be taken. They demand that a model
label: BODY

text: be developed to predict humanitarian need and to be involved in the
label: BODY

text: development of that model. The authorities limit the dataset used to train
label: BODY

text: the model in a way that leads to outcomes that overlook critical needs
label: BODY

text: for an oppressed minority. This undermines the protection of life for the
label: BODY

text: minority in question and compromises the neutrality and independence of
label: BODY

text: humanitarian organizations.
label: BODY

text: Duties of care towards
label: HH1

text: humanitarian staff
label: BODY

text: Organizations must balance their
label: BODY

text: obligations to deliver assistance
label: BODY

text: to populations in high-risk areas
label: BODY

text: with their obligations to ensure
label: BODY

text: the protection of frontline staff.
label: BODY

text: An organization needs to conduct a rapid assessment in order to respond to
label: BODY

text: a displacement in a conflict zone. The data is expected to elicit a negative
label: BODY

text: reaction from the authorities given the nature of the conflict and sensitivity
label: BODY

text: of the humanitarian response in the region in question. While the head of
label: BODY

text: office understands that there is a risk of reprisal toward staff if they proceed
label: BODY

text: with the assessment, they also know that they cannot deliver assistance
label: BODY

text: without new data. This situation creates a tension between the need to
label: BODY

text: deliver assistance and the obligation to ensure staff safety.
label: BODY

text: Cost-effectiveness conundrum
label: HH1

text: Organizations struggle to balance
label: BODY

text: doing as much good as possible
label: BODY

text: with other considerations, such
label: BODY

text: as prioritizing the worst off,
label: BODY

text: prioritising victims of intentional
label: BODY

text: brutality or continuing to assist
label: BODY

text: current aid recipients.
label: BODY

text: A model is developed to predict evolving humanitarian need. The model is
label: BODY

text: highly effective in predicting need for most of the population, resulting in a
label: BODY

text: major efficiency gain. However, communities that are less visible in the data
label: BODY

text: are now structurally disadvantaged, creating an algorithmically defined and
label: BODY

text: reinforced population that remains underserved. By obfuscating the needs
label: BODY

text: of a particular group, this undermines the impartiality of the response, calls
label: BODY

text: into question the independence of responding organizations, and endangers
label: BODY

text: the life and health of the group(s) underrepresented or missing from the
label: BODY

text: data.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

text: 1. ESTABLISH CLEAR CODES OF CONDUCT FOR ETHICAL DATA MANAGEMENT
label: HH1

text: Despite the presence of sector-wide principles and codes of conduct, humanitarians lack clear guidance
label: BODY

text: on their specific ethical obligations vis-a-vis data management. Organizations need to clarify and build
label: BODY

text: collective understanding around how the humanitarian principles and different institutional values apply
label: BODY

text: to data-related work.
label: BODY

text: To date, most organizations have focused on establishing policies on specific issues such as data
label: BODY

text: protection and data privacy, while the broader set of ethical considerations remains ill defined and
label: BODY

text: insufficiently addressed. Two notable exceptions to this that can serve as inspiration for organizations
label: BODY

text: in defining their own ethical codes of conduct for data management are the UNDG Guidance Note on
label: BODY

text: "Data Privacy, Data Protection and Ethics: Big Data for the achievement of the 2030 Agenda,"20 and the
label: BODY

text: Signal Program on Human Security and Technology’s Signal Code: Ethical Obligations for Humanitarian
label: BODY

text: Information Activities.21
label: BODY

text: •	 The UNDG Guidance Note offers an approach to big data based not only on privacy, but also on ethical
label: BODY

text: and moral obligations concerning data use in development and humanitarian contexts. It offers a set
label: BODY

text: of principles that organizations are encouraged to further adapt in the form of operational guidelines
label: BODY

text: that account for the implementation of their respective mandates as well as their existing regulations,
label: BODY

text: rules and policies concerning data privacy, data protection, data ethics and data security.
label: BODY

text: •	 The Signal Code translates and applies the foundational sources of ethical humanitarian practice to
label: BODY

text: so-called humanitarian information activities (HIAs), including data collection, storage and analysis.
label: BODY

text: It articulates nine obligations designed to help organizations understand risks and mitigate harms
label: BODY

text: related to the data life-cycle as they engage in HIAs.
label: BODY

text: 19 International Association of Professionals in Humanitarian Assistance and Protection (PHAP), Code of Ethics.
label: BODY

text: 20 UN Global Pulse, 2017. “Data Privacy, Ethics and Protection: Big Data for the achievement of the 2030 Agenda”.
label: BODY

text: 21  Signal Program on Human Security and Technology, 2018.  “The Signal Code: Ethical Obligations for Humanitarian Information Activities”.
label: BODY

text: RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPROVING ETHICAL DELIBERATION AND
label: HH1

text: DECISION-MAKING IN HUMANITARIAN DATA MANAGEMENT
label: HH1

text: When faced with different dilemmas that may arise in data-related projects, humanitarians must interpret
label: BODY

text: ethical limits and balance the various principles that inform good practice in order to determine the
label: BODY

text: appropriate course of action. As acknowledged in the International Association of Professionals in
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Assistance and Protection (PHAP) Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct, “Questions
label: BODY

text: related to ethical dilemmas are best answered by thoughtful consideration of fundamental principles,
label: BODY

text: rather than reliance on detailed regulations.”19
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data (the Centre) recommends that organizations invest in three areas to
label: BODY

text: improve ethical deliberation and decision-making in humanitarian data management:
label: BODY

text: 1.	Establish clear codes of conduct for ethical data management.
label: HH1

text: 2.	Support staff to identify, understand and debate ethical issues using common tools.
label: HH1

text: 3.	Introduce ‘ethical audits’ as part of standard practice.
label: HH1

text: 2. SUPPORT STAFF TO IDENTIFY, UNDERSTAND AND DEBATE ETHICAL ISSUES USING
label: HH1

text: COMMON TOOLS
label: HH1

text: Most humanitarian organizations do not have staff responsible for ensuring that interventions are
label: BODY

text: designed and delivered in an ethical way. Staff within humanitarian organizations are expected to
label: BODY

text: understand and abide by the humanitarian principles and related codes of conduct in going about their
label: BODY

text: respective duties, often without any formal training or guidance on the topic. Simple measures like the
label: BODY

text: introduction of an ethics checklist and supporting the use of ethical design tools can empower staff to
label: BODY

text: more confidently identify, understand and debate ethical issues that may arise in their work.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

text: Humanitarians can use the following set of questions when considering the ethical dimensions of a
label: BODY

text: particular intervention:22
label: BODY

text: •	 Are we respecting fundamental humanitarian principles and the Code of Conduct?
label: BODY

text: •	 Are we likely to increase actions that are in accordance with or in breach of International
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Law, refugee law and disaster law?23
label: BODY

text: •	 Are we likely to increase or decrease the ability of humanitarian actors to meet Sphere Standards?
label: BODY

text: •	 Are we likely to improve or worsen our target population’s dignity and conditions?
label: BODY

text: •	 Are we likely to increase or decrease our ability to abide by the principles of good humanitarian
label: BODY

text: management?
label: BODY

text: •	 Are the affected likely to understand and respect our decision?
label: BODY

text: These questions can easily be extended to humanitarian data projects and serve as a strong basis for
label: BODY

text: collective deliberation of the ethical issues that may arise therein.
label: BODY

text: Organizations can also consider ethical design tools that are more tailored to data-related projects. One
label: BODY

text: example is the “Data Ethics Canvas” from the Open Data Institute. As the ODI explains, “[t]he Data Ethics
label: BODY

text: Canvas is a tool to help anyone who collects, shares or uses data to identify and manage ethical issues
label: BODY

text: at all stages in a project. It is designed as a flexible framework to develop ethical guidance that suits any
label: BODY

text: context.”24 As such, it can serve as a helpful starting point for humanitarian organizations seeking to more
label: BODY

text: systematically manage ethical issues in data-related work.
label: BODY

text: 22 Hugo Slim, 2015. Humanitarian Ethics: A Guide to the Morality of Aid in War and Disaster, 143-144.
label: BODY

text: 23 For more on IHL, see: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law. For more on refugee law, see: https://phap.org/PHAP/Themes/Law_and_protection/IRL/
label: BODY

text: PHAP/Themes/IRL.aspx. For more on disaster law, see: https://media.ifrc.org/ifrc/what-we-do/disaster-law/.
label: BODY

text: 24 Open Data Institute, Data Ethics Canvas.
label: BODY

text: 25 iapp and UN Global Pulse, Building Ethics into Privacy Frameworks for Big Data and AI.
label: BODY

text: 26 Ibid.
label: BODY

text: 3. INTRODUCE ‘ETHICAL AUDITS’ AS PART OF STANDARD PRACTICE
label: HH1

text: To complement more robust ethical deliberation within project teams and organizations as a whole,
label: BODY

text: consider introducing quality control mechanisms that help ‘enforce’ the process of ethical design and
label: BODY

text: decision-making against a common set of criteria. One way to do this is by introducing ‘ethical audits’ as
label: BODY

text: part of standard data management practices. Such audits are particularly helpful in more exploratory areas
label: BODY

text: of data science, for which norms and professional standards are still emerging and for which the different
label: BODY

text: ethical challenges remain less well understood.
label: BODY

text: As explained in a 2017 guidance note by the International Association of Privacy Professionals and UN
label: BODY

text: Global Pulse, “[v]arious existing frameworks can supplement organizations’ decision-making processes
label: BODY

text: to address the newly emerging field of data ethics. These frameworks offer different perspectives and
label: BODY

text: governance options to organizations with weighty data ethics questions or large-scale processing
label: BODY

text: of sensitive data.”25 Ethical auditing can be achieved through internal bodies, external bodies or a
label: BODY

text: combination of the two.26
label: BODY

text: Regardless of the approach for introducing ethical audits, the process should entail the following
label: BODY

text: elements:27
label: BODY

text: •	 Identifying stakeholders affected by the data management exercise in question.
label: BODY

text: •	 Facilitating a discussion among people who can represent the different stakeholder groups and
label: BODY

text: comment on their concerns, positive and negative, on the exercise in question (e.g. how the algorithm
label: BODY

text: in a predictive model works, how their data is processed in a large scale survey exercise, etc.).
label: BODY

text: •	 Prioritizing concerns based on stakeholder inputs.
label: BODY

text: •	 Developing guidance and other measures to address and remedy concerns identified.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Spotlight: Ethics as a Core Component of Peer Review for Predictive Analytics
label: BODY

text: The Centre has established a Peer Review Framework for Predictive Analytics in Humanitarian Response. The
label: BODY

text: goal of the peer review process is to create standards and processes for the use of models in the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: sector. The Centre’s Peer Review Framework is focused on predictive model development and outputs. It
label: BODY

text: considers a model’s technical rigour, operational readiness, and related ethical concerns. Through peer review,
label: BODY

text: the Centre seeks to ensure models can be understood and trusted by all stakeholders including affected people.
label: BODY

text: The ethical review involves identifying all stakeholders and concerns related to how the model could be used.
label: BODY

text: For instance, a model may need to be adjusted in a scenario in which a false negative is unacceptable for
label: BODY

text: affected populations or a false positive is unacceptable for a donor. The ethical considerations of a given model
label: BODY

text: will be assessed using the Ethical Matrix that has been adopted from the work of Cathy O’Neil.28
label: BODY

text: Organizations are encouraged to share their experience in navigating ethical dilemmas in data management
label: BODY

text: with the Centre via centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: This project is co-funded
label: BODY

text: by the European Union
label: BODY

text: This document covers humanitarian aid activities implemented with the financial assistance of the
label: BODY

text: European Union. The views expressed herein should not be taken, in any way, to reflect the official opinion
label: BODY

text: of the European Union, and the European Commission is not responsible for any use that may be made of
label: BODY

text: the information it contains.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data, (‘the Centre’), together with key partners, is publishing a series of eight
label: BODY

text: guidance notes on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action over the course of 2019 and 2020. The Guidance
label: BODY

text: Note series follows the publication of the OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines in March 2019. Through
label: BODY

text: the series, the Centre aims to provide additional guidance on specific issues, processes and tools for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility in practice. This series is made possible with the generous support of the European Union Civil
label: BODY

text: Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (DG ECHO). This note was prepared in collaboration with O’Neil
label: BODY

text: Risk Consulting & Algorithmic Auditing, Tilburg Institute for Law, Technology, and Society, and the International
label: BODY

text: Organisation for Migration Data Science and Ethics Group.
label: BODY

text: COLLABORATORS: O'NEIL RISK CONSULTING & ALGORITHMIC AUDITING (ORCAA); TILBURG INSTITUTE FOR LAW,
label: BODY

text: TECHNOLOGY, AND SOCIETY (TILT); INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR MIGRATION (IOM) DATA SCIENCE AND
label: BODY

text: ETHICS GROUP (DSEG).
